instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.820-00239: What is 820-00239? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID_LEFT: What is SMC_LID_LEFT? SMC_LID_LEFT is a signal that tells the system if the lid is closed from the left LID sensor. If it is low, the system thinks the lid is closed – if it is 3.3v, the system thinks the machine is open. SMC_LID_LEFT needs to be high for the machine to stay awake and have a backlight. .
definitions.HALL_SENSOR_LEFT: What is HALL_SENSOR_LEFT? HALL_SENSOR_LEFT is a signal from the hall sensor on the left side of the machine that indicates that the lid has been closed. This is necessary for setting SMC_LID properly so the machine knows whether it is closed or open. When this is low, the machine will think it is closed which may cause it to go to sleep or have no backlight on the screen.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Any thoughts on what might be causing this? I've seen the lowered DC-In voltage happen on these boards with standard component failures and shorts but I'm wondering what else might cause it. Any idea where to look next on this? I'm not finding anything off. <CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR> were damaged and barely hanging on so I replaced those. I included pictures before I cleaned it but I received this board after it was already mostly cleaned so the clues aren't obvious.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: SMC needs to be running for it to enable 20V. <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I do have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: How did you replace those caps? If you used hot air near that undefilled <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> you probably screwed that.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I've replaced those caps before on this board without issue but it definitely could have been damaged something on this board. Not sure really. What is <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>? I'm going off of the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00239</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board view and schematic and don't see that.

Also, if it was damaged, any next steps?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: The USB-C controller chips CD3215C00 on this board next to those caps. It is that chip that is between the charger and SMC. So check resistors/traces/caps around that chip.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thanks, I'll check. And do they only control the USB-C ports on their side? Meaning, would the ports on one side work even if there was an issue with the circuit on the other side?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: If 1 of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is not working none of the ports will works. All chips must talk to the SMC for this shit to work. It is just a nightmare....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No Title

All I can find is that <SIGNAL>USB3_EXTA_R2D_C_N</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>USB3_EXTA_R2D_C_P</SIGNAL> are slightly higher than a good board at .430 on both versus .330 on a good board. I can't find anything else off on this. I've compared every component in the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> areas to a functional board and there's nothing else that's measuring incorrectly. The only thing I can find is that the pad for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> is disconnected and not measuring anything but all the other points on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> are measuring fine. I attached a picture of the pad I'm talking about. That's it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: You cannot verify the balls under the chip actually are connected. There could be a via under that corroded probe point. You kind of need a donor board and go dig it up to see what is going on. I would not mess with this board or pull the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> just yet. Can you source a donor for science?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I ordered some <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips from Louis. I have some donor boards coming from China too but that's going to be a while. I only have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards which appear to have a slightly different versions of the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.

If I did try to switch the chip, once I clean out the underfill, is there anything different about it compared to any other BGA? Also, I forgot to mention that <RESISTOR>R3110</RESISTOR> was blown and I switched it before my last post. No change after replacing it, but that line obviously got hit pretty hard. I have a feeling my problems all reside with this chip and the damaged caused by <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> getting burnt.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Only the older <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is available, if you have CD3215C00 you are screwed, which I'm pretty sure is on your board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I believe the 2016 15" model might have the CD3215C00 chip. Not sure, but I'm going to order some of those from China too.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have not found those chips besides on donor boards....:(

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I just realized I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I had to write off recently so I actually have the chip. Is there anything special I need to do when replacing an underfill chip?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Not really, it is just really annoying. Practice on the donor first, you can also dig out that test point and see if it affects continuity to under the chip.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I reballed that chip off of the 00840 board and it's back up and running. Thanks a lot for the help.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Actually, there's one weird issue after putting it all back together. It won't turn back on after closing the lid. No auto-turn with lid-opening either. I need to do an SMC reset to get it to turn on. If I leave it open, I can turn it on and off normally - on battery and adapter. It also won't come back on after closing the lid while it's on. Screen is black. Touch Bar is non-existent. Caps lock works. Keyboard backlight is on. Power button will NOT force quit the computer. Need to do SMC reset to shut it down.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Was there any liquid near the SMC? Could also be keyboard issue as that has the hall sensor in it I believe,

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message: SMC area wasn't hit and was clean. <SIGNAL>SMC_LID_LEFT</SIGNAL> was at around 1V vs 3.4V that it should be. <RESISTOR>R5256</RESISTOR> is good but there was a break on line leading to <RESISTOR>R5251</RESISTOR> on <SIGNAL>HALL_SENSOR_LEFT</SIGNAL>. Ran wire. All good. Thanks.
